import DarkToggle from 'components/DarkToggle'
import { BorderBox } from 'components/styles'
All the cool kids these days have websites with a dark color scheme. The really cool kids even have a dark

a light mode with a neat little toggle for you to pick your preference. Being regularly annoyed myself when browsing pages that insist on being eye-piercingly bright even late in the evening, I decided my site needs a dark mode as well. In this post, I'll share my implementation. It's API is a simple
React hook. Internally, it relies on
to persist the user's preference across visits,
a custom event bus for keeping multiple call sites to
media query to adopt the OS's color scheme (unless the user makes an explicit choice otherwise),
CSS custom properties to specify the color theme,
Gatsby's server-side rendering (SSR) API to prevent light theme colors from briefly flashing up on initial page load. (This part is separate from the
hook and not necessary if your app isn't server-rendered.)
The last two parts of this implementation were heavily inspired by
, a Gatsby core member. You can read about his dark mode implementation in
To try out the dark mode on this site, click/tap this toggle:
Here's an overview of everything we'll need to build to get this working:
component which color scheme the user prefers and provides a setter function to change the current setting.
to persist the user's preference in
hook allows us to check the
setting of the reader's device. It also sets up an event listener that updates the active theme when the state of the media query changes.
allows to pick either the dark or light color scheme or to 'unset' the preference with "auto" in which case we fall back to whatever color scheme the user's OS is currently set to.
to prevent flashing colors on initial page load.

fit together to accomplish this fairly sophisticated piece of functionality, I think it's fair to say that implementing a dark mode is an excellent use case for hooks. It demonstrates how hooks allow us to isolate and reuse pieces of logic and bring them together in ways where they become more than the sum of their parts. Or as Gabe Ragland on
It's almost as if hooks bring the compositional power of React components to stateful logic! 🤯
offers yet another simpler, although not as feature-rich
With this overview out of the way, let's get cracking.

recently landed in all major browsers including Firefox, Chrome, Safari and Edge
) we can ask the user's OS for their current color scheme in just a single line. So if the user's device is set to dark mode, the app will automatically respect that and display in dark mode as well.
You may have noted we imported three constants in

and ensure a smooth handover between the server-rendered app and its hydrated version on the clint. To make sure we don't accidentally break this handover when we change our implementation later, we create a single source of truth for both files:
hook looks a little complicated at first but that's mostly just because it includes a custom event bus. In other words, it dispatches and listens to some events that make different calls to
across the application but with the same key stay in sync. If you change the value associated with
at one call site, all others will update to this value as well.
Another option here besides custom events is to use
. By wrapping the root element of your app in a context provider whose value is the current

and its setter function, you can make both available throughout React's component tree. You can take a look at Joshua's implementation to see how to do that in Gatsby. However, I found that approach to be little more cumbersome since you need to import the React context wherever you want to use or set the current color scheme.
Last but not least in our list of hooks is

object. It couples that with a call to
indicating whether the query currently matches and registers an event listener to update that variable whenever the state of the
changes. Lastly, it accepts a callback function
that takes the current state of the query. In the case of our dark mode implementation, this will be the function that updates the values of CSS custom properties on the

component provides a three-state button to choose between dark mode, light mode or auto in which case we fall back to the OS color mode. The latter is the default value and the component just cycles through these states when clicked.
It also displays a little notification with the name of the mode for one second below the mode's icon (sun, moon or sun-slash-moon for the auto setting). It uses
to animate the icon transition between modes and a simple
The index file imports the following styled components:

Now comes the tricky SSR bit where we need to set the theme colors correctly based on the current preference prior to first paint and in particular before React even has a chance to load. As you might have guessed, that means we can only rely on browser APIs to accomplish this. No hooks, no Context API, nothing from React land will be available yet.

So much for the all of the infrastructure. All we need to do now is write some components that actually make use of our CSS custom color properties and thereby become responsive to the currently active color mode.
API which we need to implement in both

To be honest, implementing a dark mode using React hooks from start to finish took way longer and involved many more complications than I had originally anticipated. All the more reason to write this up in a blog post, right? Hopefully this is helpful to other's in the future. If you have questions, let me know in the comments!
